item.title: Do Cosmic Rays Affect Airplane Computers?
item.description: This video explores how cosmic rays interact with aircraft electronics and what engineers do to protect flight systems from rare, high-energy particle events.

media:content.media:title: Do Cosmic Rays Affect Airplane Computers?
media:content.media:description: This video explores how cosmic rays interact with aircraft electronics and what engineers do to protect flight systems from rare, high-energy particle events.

item.title: Why Earth’s Moon Doesn’t Have a Unique Name
item.description: This video explains why our Moon is usually called simply “the Moon,” exploring historical naming conventions and how the term became standard in astronomy.

item.title: Understanding Different Views on Vegetarianism
item.description: This video explores alternative perspectives on vegetarianism, examining cultural, ethical, and personal factors that shape how people approach food choices and dietary values.

item.title: A Conversation with Nobel Laureate John Martinis
item.description: In this interview, physicist John Martinis reflects on his work recognized by the Nobel Prize in Physics, discussing its impact on science and what the discovery means for future research.

item.title: Tin Cans Explained: Why They’re Made of Steel
item.description: This video clears up a common misconception by explaining why most tin cans are actually made of steel, how they’re coated, and why this design works for food storage and safety.

item.title: What It Takes to Win a Nobel Prize in Physics
item.description: Here's what you need to do in order to win a Nobel Prize in Physics �� Who knows, maybe a StarTalkian will win in the upcoming year? ��

item.title: Everything You Need to Know About the Big Dipper
item.description: This video explores the Big Dipper’s stars, its place within the Ursa Major constellation, and how it has been used for navigation and skywatching across cultures and history.

item.title: How Long Is a Year, Really?
item.description: This video explains how scientists define a year, why it is not exactly 365 days, and how Earth’s orbit and motion shape the calendar we use today.

item.title: Could Nuclear Energy Affect the Sun?
item.description: This video examines, from a physics perspective, why human-made nuclear energy would have no meaningful impact on the Sun, and how stellar energy production differs from nuclear reactions on Earth.

item.title: Are We Living in a Simulated Reality?
item.description: This video explores the simulation hypothesis as a philosophical and scientific question, outlining why some researchers discuss it and what current science can—and cannot—say about it.

item.title: A Favorite Quote From Albert Einstein
item.description: This video reflects on a memorable Albert Einstein quote and explores the idea behind it, highlighting how his words continue to inspire curiosity, science, and critical thinking today.

item.title: Why Wrong Answers Can Lead to Better Ideas
item.description: This video looks at how mistakes and incorrect answers can drive learning, creativity, and discovery, showing why progress often begins with getting something wrong.

item.title: The Hidden History of Your Phone Number
item.description: This video explores how phone numbers are assigned, what the digits represent, and how numbering systems evolved to connect people across regions and networks.

item.title: Why the Sun Doesn’t Light Up All of Space
item.description: This video explains why space remains dark despite the Sun’s brightness, exploring how light travels, spreads out, and interacts with the vacuum of space.

item.title: Where Would You End Up Digging Through Earth?
item.description: This video explains what happens if you dig straight through the Earth from the United States, using geography and physics to show where you would emerge and why the idea is mostly theoretical.

item.title: Physics, Free Will, and Human Choice
item.description: This video examines how modern physics approaches the question of free will, exploring what science can and cannot explain about human decision-making and choice.

item.title: Why Space Is Mostly Empty
item.description: This video explains why the vast majority of the universe contains very little matter, exploring atoms, distances between stars, and what “empty” really means in modern physics.

item.title: Why Daylight Saving Time Exists
item.description: This video explains daylight saving time, how it began, how the clock changes work, and why different countries choose to observe it or not.

item.title: Fahrenheit vs. Celsius Explained
item.description: This video compares the Fahrenheit and Celsius temperature scales, explaining how each was developed, how they differ, and why different regions use different systems today.

item.title: Why We Rely on Experiments
item.description: This video explains the role of experiments in science, showing how testing ideas helps researchers gather evidence, reduce uncertainty, and build reliable knowledge about the world.
